dn31:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
dn31:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

dn31:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena siṅgālako gahapatiputto kālasseva uṭṭhāya rājagahā nikkhamitvā allavattho allakeso pañjaliko puthudisā namassati—
dn31:1.3.eng: Now at that time the householder’s son Sigālaka rose early and left Rājagaha. With his clothes and hair all wet, he raised his joined palms to revere the various quarters—
dn31:1.3.comm: Sigālaka only appears in this sutta. His name means “little jackal”.

dn31:1.4.pli: puratthimaṃ disaṃ dakkhiṇaṃ disaṃ pacchimaṃ disaṃ uttaraṃ disaṃ heṭṭhimaṃ disaṃ uparimaṃ disaṃ.
dn31:1.4.eng: east, south, west, north, below, and above.
dn31:1.4.comm: Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 5.5.1 recommends offerings to Agni in the east, Indra or Soma in the south, the All-gods in the west, Mitra and Varuṇa in the north, and Bṛhaspati in the middle. The quarters themselves are divine, since one can travel them and never reach the end (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.1.5). Atharva Veda 12.3.7–10 gives a domestic prayer for the quarters; here Yama dwells in the south with the Fathers, while Soma is in the west, and the other directions are not associated with specific deities. Vājasaneyi Saṁhitā 22.24a worships the six directions. Maitrī Upaniṣad 7.1–6 details the spiritual meanings of the six quarters. In Buddhism, the quarters are said to be inhabited by the respective Four Great Kings as per DN 32.

dn31:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya rājagahaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
dn31:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Rājagaha for alms.

dn31:2.2.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā siṅgālakaṃ gahapatiputtaṃ kālasseva vuṭṭhāya rājagahā nikkhamitvā allavatthaṃ allakesaṃ pañjalikaṃ puthudisā namassantaṃ—
dn31:2.2.eng: He saw Sigālaka revering the various quarters

dn31:2.3.pli: puratthimaṃ disaṃ dakkhiṇaṃ disaṃ pacchimaṃ disaṃ uttaraṃ disaṃ heṭṭhimaṃ disaṃ uparimaṃ disaṃ.

dn31:2.5.pli: “kiṃ nu kho tvaṃ, gahapatiputta, kālasseva vuṭṭhāya rājagahā nikkhamitvā allavattho allakeso pañjaliko puthudisā namassasi—
dn31:2.5.eng: “Householder’s son, why are you revering the various quarters in this way?”

dn31:2.6.pli: puratthimaṃ disaṃ dakkhiṇaṃ disaṃ pacchimaṃ disaṃ uttaraṃ disaṃ heṭṭhimaṃ disaṃ uparimaṃ disan”ti?

dn31:2.7.pli: “Pitā maṃ, bhante, kālaṃ karonto evaṃ avaca:
dn31:2.7.eng: “Sir, on his deathbed my father said to me:

dn31:2.8.comm: Sigālaka followed blindly without considering the meaning as urged by Chāndogya Upaniṣad 1.3.11.

dn31:2.9.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhante, pituvacanaṃ sakkaronto garuṃ karonto mānento pūjento kālasseva uṭṭhāya rājagahā nikkhamitvā allavattho allakeso pañjaliko puthudisā namassāmi—
dn31:2.9.eng: Honoring, respecting, and venerating my father’s words, I rose early and left Rājagaha and, with my clothes and hair all wet, raised my joined palms to revere the various quarters—

dn31:2.10.pli: puratthimaṃ disaṃ dakkhiṇaṃ disaṃ pacchimaṃ disaṃ uttaraṃ disaṃ heṭṭhimaṃ disaṃ uparimaṃ disan”ti.
dn31:2.10.eng: east, south, west, north, below, and above.”

dn31:2.12.pli: “Na kho, gahapatiputta, ariyassa vinaye evaṃ cha disā namassitabbā”ti.
dn31:2.12.eng: “Householder’s son, that’s not how the six directions should be revered in the training of the Noble One.”
dn31:2.12.comm: It is unusual to find “six” directions. Normally it is four, then eight (with intermediate directions), then ten (above and below). Praśna Upaniṣad 1.6 lists the six, then the intermediates.

dn31:2.13.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana, bhante, ariyassa vinaye cha disā namassitabbā?
dn31:2.13.eng: “But sir, how should the six directions be revered in the training of the Noble One?

dn31:2.14.pli: Sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā tathā dhammaṃ desetu, yathā ariyassa vinaye cha disā namassitabbā”ti.

dn31:2.15.pli: “Tena hi, gahapatiputta, suṇohi sādhukaṃ manasikarohi bhāsissāmī”ti.
dn31:2.15.eng: “Well then, householder’s son, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

dn31:2.16.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho siṅgālako gahapatiputto bhagavato paccassosi.

dn31:3.1.pli: “Yato kho, gahapatiputta, ariyasāvakassa cattāro kammakilesā pahīnā honti, catūhi ca ṭhānehi pāpakammaṃ na karoti, cha ca bhogānaṃ apāyamukhāni na sevati, so evaṃ cuddasa pāpakāpagato chaddisāpaṭicchādī
dn31:3.1.eng: “Householder’s son, a noble disciple gives up four corrupt deeds, doesn’t do bad deeds on four grounds, and avoids six drains on wealth. When they’ve left these fourteen bad things behind they have the six directions covered.
dn31:3.1.comm: The Buddha outlines the contents of the discourse to follow.

dn31:3.2.pli: ubholokavijayāya paṭipanno hoti. Tassa ayañceva loko āraddho hoti paro ca loko.
dn31:3.2.eng: They’re practicing to win in both worlds, and they succeed in this world and the next.

dn31:3.3.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
dn31:3.3.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

dn31:3.5.eng: What four corrupt deeds have they given up?
dn31:3.5.comm: The teaching is structured to reinforce memorization. Give the number of items (twice), so you will notice if any are missing; list the items; recapitulate the numbers; then recapitulate the items once more in verse.

dn31:3.6.pli: Pāṇātipāto kho, gahapatiputta, kammakileso, adinnādānaṃ kammakileso, kāmesumicchācāro kammakileso, musāvādo kammakileso.
dn31:3.6.eng: Killing living creatures, stealing, sexual misconduct, and lying: these are corrupt deeds.

dn31:3.7.eng: These are the four corrupt deeds they’ve given up.”

dn31:3.8.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

dn31:3.9.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
dn31:3.9.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

dn31:4.4.eng: astute people don’t praise these things.”

dn31:5.1.eng: “On what four grounds do they not do bad deeds?
dn31:5.1.comm: First we learned what the bad deeds were, now we learn why people do them.

dn31:5.2.pli: Chandāgatiṃ gacchanto pāpakammaṃ karoti, dosāgatiṃ gacchanto pāpakammaṃ karoti, mohāgatiṃ gacchanto pāpakammaṃ karoti, bhayāgatiṃ gacchanto pāpakammaṃ karoti.
dn31:5.2.eng: One does bad deeds prejudiced by favoritism, hostility, stupidity, and cowardice.

dn31:5.3.pli: Yato kho, gahapatiputta, ariyasāvako neva chandāgatiṃ gacchati, na dosāgatiṃ gacchati, na mohāgatiṃ gacchati, na bhayāgatiṃ gacchati;
dn31:5.3.eng: When a noble disciple is not prejudiced by favoritism, hostility, stupidity, and cowardice,

dn31:5.4.pli: imehi catūhi ṭhānehi pāpakammaṃ na karotī”ti.
dn31:5.4.eng: they don’t do bad deeds on these four grounds.”

dn31:5.5.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

dn31:5.6.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
dn31:5.6.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

dn31:6.2.eng: out of favoritism, hostility, cowardice, or stupidity,

dn31:6.4.eng: like the moon in the waning fortnight.

dn31:6.5.eng: If you don’t act against the teaching

dn31:6.6.eng: out of favoritism, hostility, cowardice, and stupidity,

dn31:6.8.eng: like the moon in the waxing fortnight.”

dn31:7.1.eng: “What six drains on wealth do they avoid?
dn31:7.1.comm: “Drains on wealth” is apāyamukha, literally “openings for departure”. This is emphasized here since Sigālaka wants to be a good son and not squander the family fortune.

dn31:7.2.pli: Surāmerayamajjappamādaṭṭhānānuyogo kho, gahapatiputta, bhogānaṃ apāyamukhaṃ, vikālavisikhācariyānuyogo bhogānaṃ apāyamukhaṃ, samajjābhicaraṇaṃ bhogānaṃ apāyamukhaṃ, jūtappamādaṭṭhānānuyogo bhogānaṃ apāyamukhaṃ, pāpamittānuyogo bhogānaṃ apāyamukhaṃ, ālasyānuyogo bhogānaṃ apāyamukhaṃ.
dn31:7.2.eng: Habitually engaging in the following things is a drain on wealth: consuming beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants; roaming the streets at night; frequenting festivals; gambling; bad friends; laziness.
dn31:7.2.comm: The most common phrase in Pali for alcoholic beverages lists three items. Surā is brewed from grains with yeast (Bu Pc 51:2.1.2) Meraya is made from flowers, fruits, or sugars (Bu Pc 51:2.1.4). Madya is apparently a catchall. Together they correspond fairly well with the modern classification of alcoholic drinks as “beer, wine, and liquor”. See also Manu 11.94, Arthaśāstra 2.25, Suśrutasaṁhitā 1.45, Amarakośodghāṭana 3.6.

dn31:8.1.eng: There are these six drawbacks of habitually consuming beer, wine, and liquor that cause intoxication.
dn31:8.1.comm: Now each of the six drains on wealth are expanded and explained.

dn31:8.2.pli: Sandiṭṭhikā dhanajāni, kalahappavaḍḍhanī, rogānaṃ āyatanaṃ, akittisañjananī, kopīnanidaṃsanī, paññāya dubbalikaraṇītveva chaṭṭhaṃ padaṃ bhavati.
dn31:8.2.eng: Immediate loss of wealth, promotion of quarrels, susceptibility to illness, disrepute, indecent exposure; and weakened wisdom is the sixth thing.

dn31:8.3.pli: Ime kho, gahapatiputta, cha ādīnavā surāmerayamajjappamādaṭṭhānānuyoge.
dn31:8.3.eng: These are the six drawbacks of habitually consuming beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.

dn31:9.0.eng: 6. Six Drawbacks of Roaming the Streets at Night

dn31:9.1.eng: There are these six drawbacks of roaming the streets at night.

dn31:9.2.pli: Attāpissa agutto arakkhito hoti, puttadāropissa agutto arakkhito hoti, sāpateyyampissa aguttaṃ arakkhitaṃ hoti, saṅkiyo ca hoti pāpakesu ṭhānesu, abhūtavacanañca tasmiṃ rūhati, bahūnañca dukkhadhammānaṃ purakkhato hoti.
dn31:9.2.eng: Yourself, your partners and children, and your property are all left unguarded. You’re suspected of bad deeds. Untrue rumors spread about you. You’re at the forefront of many things that entail suffering.

dn31:9.3.pli: Ime kho, gahapatiputta, cha ādīnavā vikālavisikhācariyānuyoge.
dn31:9.3.eng: These are the six drawbacks of roaming the streets at night.

dn31:10.1.eng: There are these six drawbacks of frequenting festivals.

dn31:10.2.pli: Kva naccaṃ, kva gītaṃ, kva vāditaṃ, kva akkhānaṃ, kva pāṇissaraṃ, kva kumbhathunanti.
dn31:10.2.eng: You’re always thinking: ‘Where’s the dancing? Where’s the singing? Where’s the music? Where are the stories? Where’s the applause? Where are the kettledrums?’

dn31:10.3.pli: Ime kho, gahapatiputta, cha ādīnavā samajjābhicaraṇe.
dn31:10.3.eng: These are the six drawbacks of frequenting festivals.

dn31:11.1.eng: There are these six drawbacks of habitually gambling.

dn31:11.2.pli: Jayaṃ veraṃ pasavati, jino vittamanusocati, sandiṭṭhikā dhanajāni, sabhāgatassa vacanaṃ na rūhati, mittāmaccānaṃ paribhūto hoti, āvāhavivāhakānaṃ apatthito hoti:
dn31:11.2.eng: Victory breeds enmity. The loser mourns their money. There is immediate loss of wealth. A gambler’s word carries no weight in public assembly. Friends and colleagues treat them with contempt. And no-one wants to marry a gambler, for they think:

dn31:11.3.eng: ‘This individual is a gambler—they’re not able to support a partner.’

dn31:11.4.pli: Ime kho, gahapatiputta, cha ādīnavā jūtappamādaṭṭhānānuyoge.
dn31:11.4.eng: These are the six drawbacks of habitually gambling.

dn31:12.1.eng: There are these six drawbacks of bad friends.

dn31:12.2.pli: Ye dhuttā, ye soṇḍā, ye pipāsā, ye nekatikā, ye vañcanikā, ye sāhasikā. Tyāssa mittā honti te sahāyā.
dn31:12.2.eng: You become friends and companions with those who are addicts, carousers, drunkards, frauds, swindlers, and thugs.

dn31:12.3.pli: Ime kho, gahapatiputta, cha ādīnavā pāpamittānuyoge.
dn31:12.3.eng: These are the six drawbacks of bad friends.

dn31:13.1.eng: There are these six drawbacks of habitual laziness.

dn31:13.2.pli: Atisītanti kammaṃ na karoti, atiuṇhanti kammaṃ na karoti, atisāyanti kammaṃ na karoti, atipātoti kammaṃ na karoti, atichātosmīti kammaṃ na karoti, atidhātosmīti kammaṃ na karoti.
dn31:13.2.eng: You don’t get your work done because you think: ‘It’s too cold! It’s too hot. It’s too late! It’s too early! I’m too hungry! I’m too full!’

dn31:13.3.pli: Tassa evaṃ kiccāpadesabahulassa viharato anuppannā ceva bhogā nuppajjanti, uppannā ca bhogā parikkhayaṃ gacchanti.
dn31:13.3.eng: By dwelling on so many excuses for not working, you don’t make any more money, and the money you already have runs out.

dn31:13.4.pli: Ime kho, gahapatiputta, cha ādīnavā ālasyānuyoge”ti.
dn31:13.4.eng: These are the six drawbacks of habitual laziness.”

dn31:13.5.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

dn31:13.6.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
dn31:13.6.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

dn31:14.2.eng: some call you their dear, dear friend,

dn31:14.3.eng: but a true friend is one

dn31:14.4.eng: who stands by you in need.

dn31:14.8.eng: these six grounds ruin a person.

dn31:14.12.eng: in both this world and the next.

dn31:14.13.eng: Dice, women, toddy, song and dance;
dn31:14.13.comm: Vārunī is said to have been distilled from hogweed with palm sap, “toddy”.

dn31:14.14.eng: sleeping by day and roaming at night;

dn31:14.16.eng: these six grounds ruin a person.

dn31:14.17.eng: They play dice and drink beer,

dn31:14.18.eng: and consort with women loved by others.

dn31:14.19.eng: Associating with the worse, not the better,

dn31:14.20.eng: they diminish like the waning moon.

dn31:14.21.eng: One who is broke and destitute due to toddy,
dn31:14.21.comm: Assume vāruṇī is a truncated instrumental.

dn31:14.24.comm: Kāhiti is third person singular future of karoti.

dn31:14.25.eng: When you’re in the habit of sleeping late,

dn31:14.26.eng: seeing night as time to rise,

dn31:14.28.eng: you can’t keep up the household life.

dn31:14.31.eng: When the young neglect their work like this,

dn31:14.32.comm: The subcommentary explains atthā as dhanā (“riches”).

dn31:14.33.eng: But one who considers heat and cold

dn31:14.34.eng: as no more than blades of grass—

dn31:14.35.eng: he does his duties as a man,

dn31:15.1.eng: “Householder’s son, you should recognize these four enemies disguised as friends:

dn31:15.2.pli: Aññadatthuharo amitto mittapatirūpako veditabbo, vacīparamo amitto mittapatirūpako veditabbo, anuppiyabhāṇī amitto mittapatirūpako veditabbo, apāyasahāyo amitto mittapatirūpako veditabbo.
dn31:15.2.eng: the taker, the talker, the flatterer, the spender.

dn31:16.1.pli: Catūhi kho, gahapatiputta, ṭhānehi aññadatthuharo amitto mittapatirūpako veditabbo.
dn31:16.1.eng: You can recognize a fake friend who’s all take on four grounds.

dn31:16.3.eng: Giving little, they expect a lot.

dn31:16.4.eng: They do their duty out of fear.

dn31:16.5.eng: They associate for their own advantage.

dn31:16.6.pli: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, catūhi ṭhānehi aññadatthuharo amitto mittapatirūpako veditabbo.
dn31:16.6.eng: You can recognize a fake friend who’s all take on these four grounds.

dn31:17.1.pli: Catūhi kho, gahapatiputta, ṭhānehi vacīparamo amitto mittapatirūpako veditabbo.
dn31:17.1.eng: You can recognize a fake friend who’s all talk on four grounds.

dn31:17.2.pli: Atītena paṭisantharati, anāgatena paṭisantharati, niratthakena saṅgaṇhāti, paccuppannesu kiccesu byasanaṃ dasseti.
dn31:17.2.eng: They’re hospitable in the past. They’re hospitable in the future. They’re full of meaningless pleasantries. When something needs doing in the present they point to their own misfortune.

dn31:17.3.pli: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, catūhi ṭhānehi vacīparamo amitto mittapatirūpako veditabbo.
dn31:17.3.eng: You can recognize a fake friend who’s all talk on these four grounds.

dn31:18.1.pli: Catūhi kho, gahapatiputta, ṭhānehi anuppiyabhāṇī amitto mittapatirūpako veditabbo.
dn31:18.1.eng: You can recognize a fake friend who’s a flatterer on four grounds.

dn31:18.2.pli: Pāpakampissa anujānāti, kalyāṇampissa anujānāti, sammukhāssa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, parammukhāssa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati.
dn31:18.2.eng: They support you equally in doing bad and doing good. They praise you to your face, and put you down behind your back.

dn31:18.3.pli: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, catūhi ṭhānehi anuppiyabhāṇī amitto mittapatirūpako veditabbo.
dn31:18.3.eng: You can recognize a fake friend who’s a flatterer on these four grounds.

dn31:19.1.pli: Catūhi kho, gahapatiputta, ṭhānehi apāyasahāyo amitto mittapatirūpako veditabbo.
dn31:19.1.eng: You can recognize a fake friend who’s a spender on four grounds.

dn31:19.2.pli: Surāmerayamajjappamādaṭṭhānānuyoge sahāyo hoti, vikālavisikhācariyānuyoge sahāyo hoti, samajjābhicaraṇe sahāyo hoti, jūtappamādaṭṭhānānuyoge sahāyo hoti.
dn31:19.2.eng: They accompany you when drinking, roaming the streets at night, frequenting festivals, and gambling.

dn31:19.3.pli: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, catūhi ṭhānehi apāyasahāyo amitto mittapatirūpako veditabbo”ti.
dn31:19.3.eng: You can recognize a fake friend who’s a spender on these four grounds.”

dn31:19.4.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

dn31:19.5.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
dn31:19.5.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

dn31:20.4.eng: and one’s a comrade who spends.

dn31:20.6.eng: these four enemies for what they are

dn31:20.7.eng: and keeps them at a distance,

dn31:20.8.eng: as they’d shun a risky road.”

dn31:21.1.eng: “Householder’s son, you should recognize these four good-hearted friends:

dn31:21.2.pli: Upakāro mitto suhado veditabbo, samānasukhadukkho mitto suhado veditabbo, atthakkhāyī mitto suhado veditabbo, anukampako mitto suhado veditabbo.
dn31:21.2.eng: the helper, the friend in good times and bad, the counselor, and the one who’s sympathetic.

dn31:22.1.pli: Catūhi kho, gahapatiputta, ṭhānehi upakāro mitto suhado veditabbo.
dn31:22.1.eng: You can recognize a good-hearted friend who’s a helper on four grounds.

dn31:22.2.pli: Pamattaṃ rakkhati, pamattassa sāpateyyaṃ rakkhati, bhītassa saraṇaṃ hoti, uppannesu kiccakaraṇīyesu taddiguṇaṃ bhogaṃ anuppadeti.
dn31:22.2.eng: They guard you when you’re negligent. They guard your property when you’re negligent. They keep you safe in times of danger. When something needs doing, they provide you with twice the money you need.

dn31:22.3.pli: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, catūhi ṭhānehi upakāro mitto suhado veditabbo.
dn31:22.3.eng: You can recognize a good-hearted friend who’s a helper on these four grounds.

dn31:23.1.pli: Catūhi kho, gahapatiputta, ṭhānehi samānasukhadukkho mitto suhado veditabbo.
dn31:23.1.eng: You can recognize a good-hearted friend who’s the same in good times and bad on four grounds.

dn31:23.2.pli: Guyhamassa ācikkhati, guyhamassa parigūhati, āpadāsu na vijahati, jīvitaṃpissa atthāya pariccattaṃ hoti.
dn31:23.2.eng: They tell you secrets. They keep your secrets. They don’t abandon you in times of trouble. They’d even give their life for your welfare.

dn31:23.3.pli: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, catūhi ṭhānehi samānasukhadukkho mitto suhado veditabbo.
dn31:23.3.eng: You can recognize a good-hearted friend who’s the same in good times and bad on these four grounds.

dn31:24.1.pli: Catūhi kho, gahapatiputta, ṭhānehi atthakkhāyī mitto suhado veditabbo.
dn31:24.1.eng: You can recognize a good-hearted friend who’s a counselor on four grounds.

dn31:24.2.pli: Pāpā nivāreti, kalyāṇe niveseti, assutaṃ sāveti, saggassa maggaṃ ācikkhati.
dn31:24.2.eng: They keep you from doing bad. They support you in doing good. They teach you what you do not know. They explain the path to heaven.

dn31:24.3.pli: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, catūhi ṭhānehi atthakkhāyī mitto suhado veditabbo.
dn31:24.3.eng: You can recognize a good-hearted friend who’s a counselor on these four grounds.

dn31:25.1.pli: Catūhi kho, gahapatiputta, ṭhānehi anukampako mitto suhado veditabbo.
dn31:25.1.eng: You can recognize a good-hearted friend who’s sympathetic on four grounds.

dn31:25.2.pli: Abhavenassa na nandati, bhavenassa nandati, avaṇṇaṃ bhaṇamānaṃ nivāreti, vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇamānaṃ pasaṃsati.
dn31:25.2.eng: They don’t delight in your misfortune. They delight in your good fortune. They keep others from criticizing you. They encourage praise of you.

dn31:25.3.pli: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, catūhi ṭhānehi anukampako mitto suhado veditabbo”ti.
dn31:25.3.eng: You can recognize a good-hearted friend who’s sympathetic on these four grounds.”

dn31:25.5.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
dn31:25.5.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

dn31:26.2.eng: one the same in both pleasure and pain,

dn31:26.6.eng: these four friends for what they are

dn31:26.8.eng: like a mother the child at her breast.

dn31:26.11.eng: They pick up riches as bees

dn31:26.13.eng: And their riches proceed to grow,

dn31:26.14.eng: like a termite mound piling up.

dn31:26.16.eng: a householder does enough for their family.

dn31:26.17.eng: And they’d hold on to friends

dn31:26.18.eng: by dividing their wealth in four.

dn31:26.21.eng: And the fourth should be kept

dn31:27.1.eng: “And how, householder’s son, does a noble disciple cover the six directions?
dn31:27.1.comm: Having explained the six drains on wealth, the Buddha moves on to the next item in the table of contents.

dn31:27.2.eng: These six directions should be recognized:

dn31:27.3.pli: Puratthimā disā mātāpitaro veditabbā, dakkhiṇā disā ācariyā veditabbā, pacchimā disā puttadārā veditabbā, uttarā disā mittāmaccā veditabbā, heṭṭhimā disā dāsakammakarā veditabbā, uparimā disā samaṇabrāhmaṇā veditabbā.
dn31:27.3.eng: parents as the east, tutors as the south, partner and children as the west, friends and colleagues as the north, bondservants and workers as beneath, and ascetics and brahmins as above.
dn31:27.3.comm: Parents are in the east because that is where the sun is born. Tutors are to the south (dakkhiṇā) as they are owed an offering (dakkhiṇā). Family is one’s legacy, so they lie with the setting sun in the west. Good friends keep you on the upright way to the north. Servants support you and make your life possible, like the earth below. And spiritual teachers lead you to heaven or transcendence above.

dn31:28.1.pli: Pañcahi kho, gahapatiputta, ṭhānehi puttena puratthimā disā mātāpitaro paccupaṭṭhātabbā—
dn31:28.1.eng: A child should serve their parents as the eastern quarter in five ways, thinking:

dn31:28.2.pli: bhato ne bharissāmi, kiccaṃ nesaṃ karissāmi, kulavaṃsaṃ ṭhapessāmi, dāyajjaṃ paṭipajjāmi, atha vā pana petānaṃ kālaṅkatānaṃ dakkhiṇaṃ anuppadassāmīti.
dn31:28.2.eng: ‘I will support those who supported me. I’ll do my duty for them. I’ll maintain the family lineage. I’ll take care of the inheritance. When they have passed away, I’ll make an offering on their behalf.’

dn31:28.3.pli: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, pañcahi ṭhānehi puttena puratthimā disā mātāpitaro paccupaṭṭhitā pañcahi ṭhānehi puttaṃ anukampanti.
dn31:28.3.eng: Parents served by the children in these five ways show sympathy to them in five ways.

dn31:28.4.pli: Pāpā nivārenti, kalyāṇe nivesenti, sippaṃ sikkhāpenti, patirūpena dārena saṃyojenti, samaye dāyajjaṃ niyyādenti.
dn31:28.4.eng: They keep them from doing bad. They support them in doing good. They train them in a profession. They connect them with a suitable partner. They transfer the inheritance in due time.

dn31:28.5.pli: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, pañcahi ṭhānehi puttena puratthimā disā mātāpitaro paccupaṭṭhitā imehi pañcahi ṭhānehi puttaṃ anukampanti.
dn31:28.5.eng: Parents served by their children in these five ways show sympathy to them in these five ways.

dn31:28.6.pli: Evamassa esā puratthimā disā paṭicchannā hoti khemā appaṭibhayā.
dn31:28.6.eng: And that’s how the eastern quarter is covered, kept safe and free of peril.

dn31:29.1.pli: Pañcahi kho, gahapatiputta, ṭhānehi antevāsinā dakkhiṇā disā ācariyā paccupaṭṭhātabbā—
dn31:29.1.eng: A pupil should serve their tutor as the southern quarter in five ways:

dn31:29.2.pli: uṭṭhānena upaṭṭhānena sussusāya pāricariyāya sakkaccaṃ sippapaṭiggahaṇena.
dn31:29.2.eng: by rising for them, by serving them, by listening well, by looking after them, and by carefully learning their profession.

dn31:29.3.pli: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, pañcahi ṭhānehi antevāsinā dakkhiṇā disā ācariyā paccupaṭṭhitā pañcahi ṭhānehi antevāsiṃ anukampanti—
dn31:29.3.eng: Tutors served by their pupils in these five ways show sympathy to them in five ways.

dn31:29.4.pli: suvinītaṃ vinenti, suggahitaṃ gāhāpenti, sabbasippassutaṃ samakkhāyino bhavanti, mittāmaccesu paṭiyādenti, disāsu parittāṇaṃ karonti.
dn31:29.4.eng: They make sure they’re well educated and well drilled in memorization. They clearly explain all the knowledge of the profession. They introduce them to their friends and colleagues. They provide protection in every region.
dn31:29.4.comm: “Protection in every region” (disāsu parittāṇaṁ) refers to when the student has completed their studies and goes off to travel, the teacher does what they can to ensure their safety in other regions.

dn31:29.5.pli: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, pañcahi ṭhānehi antevāsinā dakkhiṇā disā ācariyā paccupaṭṭhitā imehi pañcahi ṭhānehi antevāsiṃ anukampanti.
dn31:29.5.eng: Tutors served by their pupils in these five ways show sympathy to them in these five ways.

dn31:29.6.pli: Evamassa esā dakkhiṇā disā paṭicchannā hoti khemā appaṭibhayā.
dn31:29.6.eng: And that’s how the southern quarter is covered, kept safe and free of peril.

dn31:30.1.pli: Pañcahi kho, gahapatiputta, ṭhānehi sāmikena pacchimā disā bhariyā paccupaṭṭhātabbā—
dn31:30.1.eng: A husband should serve his wife as the western quarter in five ways:

dn31:30.2.eng: by treating her with honor, by not looking down on her, by not being unfaithful, by relinquishing authority to her, and by presenting her with adornments.
dn31:30.2.comm: Marriage is based on mutual care and respect, not on dominance and obedience.

dn31:30.3.pli: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, pañcahi ṭhānehi sāmikena pacchimā disā bhariyā paccupaṭṭhitā pañcahi ṭhānehi sāmikaṃ anukampati—
dn31:30.3.eng: A wife served by her husband in these five ways shows sympathy to him in five ways.

dn31:30.4.pli: susaṃvihitakammantā ca hoti, saṅgahitaparijanā ca, anaticārinī ca, sambhatañca anurakkhati, dakkhā ca hoti analasā sabbakiccesu.
dn31:30.4.eng: She’s well-organized in her work. She manages the domestic help. She’s not unfaithful. She preserves his earnings. She’s deft and tireless in all her duties.

dn31:30.5.pli: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, pañcahi ṭhānehi sāmikena pacchimā disā bhariyā paccupaṭṭhitā imehi pañcahi ṭhānehi sāmikaṃ anukampati.
dn31:30.5.eng: A wife served by her husband in these five ways shows sympathy to him in these five ways.

dn31:30.6.pli: Evamassa esā pacchimā disā paṭicchannā hoti khemā appaṭibhayā.
dn31:30.6.eng: And that’s how the western quarter is covered, kept safe and free of peril.

dn31:31.1.pli: Pañcahi kho, gahapatiputta, ṭhānehi kulaputtena uttarā disā mittāmaccā paccupaṭṭhātabbā—
dn31:31.1.eng: A gentleman should serve his friends and colleagues as the northern quarter in five ways:

dn31:31.2.eng: giving, kindly words, taking care, equality, and not using tricky words.

dn31:31.3.pli: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, pañcahi ṭhānehi kulaputtena uttarā disā mittāmaccā paccupaṭṭhitā pañcahi ṭhānehi kulaputtaṃ anukampanti—
dn31:31.3.eng: Friends and colleagues served by a gentleman in these five ways show sympathy to him in five ways.

dn31:31.4.pli: pamattaṃ rakkhanti, pamattassa sāpateyyaṃ rakkhanti, bhītassa saraṇaṃ honti, āpadāsu na vijahanti, aparapajā cassa paṭipūjenti.
dn31:31.4.eng: They guard him when they’re negligent. They guard his property when they’re negligent. They keep him safe in times of danger. They don’t abandon him in times of trouble. They honor his descendants.

dn31:31.5.pli: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, pañcahi ṭhānehi kulaputtena uttarā disā mittāmaccā paccupaṭṭhitā imehi pañcahi ṭhānehi kulaputtaṃ anukampanti.
dn31:31.5.eng: Friends and colleagues served by a gentleman in these five ways show sympathy to him in these five ways.

dn31:31.6.pli: Evamassa esā uttarā disā paṭicchannā hoti khemā appaṭibhayā.
dn31:31.6.eng: And that’s how the northern quarter is covered, kept safe and free of peril.

dn31:32.1.pli: Pañcahi kho, gahapatiputta, ṭhānehi ayyirakena heṭṭhimā disā dāsakammakarā paccupaṭṭhātabbā—
dn31:32.1.eng: A master should serve their bondservants and workers as the lower quarter in five ways:

dn31:32.2.pli: yathābalaṃ kammantasaṃvidhānena bhattavetanānuppadānena gilānupaṭṭhānena acchariyānaṃ rasānaṃ saṃvibhāgena samaye vossaggena.
dn31:32.2.eng: by organizing work according to ability, by paying food and wages, by nursing them when sick, by sharing special treats, and by giving time off work.

dn31:32.3.pli: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, pañcahi ṭhānehi ayyirakena heṭṭhimā disā dāsakammakarā paccupaṭṭhitā pañcahi ṭhānehi ayyirakaṃ anukampanti—
dn31:32.3.eng: Bondservants and workers served by a master in these five ways show sympathy to him in five ways.

dn31:32.4.pli: pubbuṭṭhāyino ca honti, pacchā nipātino ca, dinnādāyino ca, sukatakammakarā ca, kittivaṇṇaharā ca.
dn31:32.4.eng: They get up first, and go to bed last. They don’t steal. They do their work well. And they promote a good reputation.

dn31:32.5.pli: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, pañcahi ṭhānehi ayyirakena heṭṭhimā disā dāsakammakarā paccupaṭṭhitā imehi pañcahi ṭhānehi ayyirakaṃ anukampanti.
dn31:32.5.eng: Bondservants and workers served by a master in these five ways show sympathy to him in these five ways.

dn31:32.6.pli: Evamassa esā heṭṭhimā disā paṭicchannā hoti khemā appaṭibhayā.
dn31:32.6.eng: And that’s how the lower quarter is covered, kept safe and free of peril.

dn31:33.1.pli: Pañcahi kho, gahapatiputta, ṭhānehi kulaputtena uparimā disā samaṇabrāhmaṇā paccupaṭṭhātabbā—
dn31:33.1.eng: A gentleman should serve ascetics and brahmins as the upper quarter in five ways:

dn31:33.2.pli: mettena kāyakammena mettena vacīkammena mettena manokammena anāvaṭadvāratāya āmisānuppadānena.
dn31:33.2.eng: by loving deeds of body, speech, and mind, by not turning them away at the gate, and by providing them with material needs.

dn31:33.3.pli: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, pañcahi ṭhānehi kulaputtena uparimā disā samaṇabrāhmaṇā paccupaṭṭhitā chahi ṭhānehi kulaputtaṃ anukampanti—
dn31:33.3.eng: Ascetics and brahmins served by a gentleman in these five ways show sympathy to him in six ways.

dn31:33.4.pli: pāpā nivārenti, kalyāṇe nivesenti, kalyāṇena manasā anukampanti, assutaṃ sāventi, sutaṃ pariyodāpenti, saggassa maggaṃ ācikkhanti.
dn31:33.4.eng: They keep him from doing bad. They support him in doing good. They think of him with kindly thoughts. They teach him what he does not know. They clarify what he’s already learned. They explain the path to heaven.

dn31:33.5.pli: Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, pañcahi ṭhānehi kulaputtena uparimā disā samaṇabrāhmaṇā paccupaṭṭhitā imehi chahi ṭhānehi kulaputtaṃ anukampanti.
dn31:33.5.eng: Ascetics and brahmins served by a gentleman in these five ways show sympathy to him in these six ways.

dn31:33.6.pli: Evamassa esā uparimā disā paṭicchannā hoti khemā appaṭibhayā”ti.
dn31:33.6.eng: And that’s how the upper quarter is covered, kept safe and free of peril.”

dn31:33.8.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
dn31:33.8.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

dn31:34.8.eng: a householder does enough for their family.

dn31:34.12.eng: they’re the kind who win glory.

dn31:34.15.eng: those consistent in conduct, the intelligent:

dn31:34.16.eng: they’re the kind who win glory.

dn31:34.17.eng: The inclusive, the makers of friends,

dn31:34.18.eng: the bountiful, those rid of stinginess,

dn31:34.19.eng: those who lead, train, and persuade:

dn31:34.20.eng: they’re the kind who win glory.

dn31:34.23.eng: and treating equally in worldly conditions,

dn31:34.24.eng: as they deserve in each case;

dn31:34.25.eng: these ways of being inclusive in the world

dn31:34.26.eng: are like a moving chariot’s linchpin.

dn31:34.27.eng: If there were no such ways of being inclusive,

dn31:34.30.eng: for what they’ve done for their children.

dn31:34.31.eng: But since these ways of being inclusive do exist,

dn31:34.32.eng: the astute do regard them well,

dn31:35.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, siṅgālako gahapatiputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn31:35.1.eng: When this was said, Sigālaka the householder’s son said to the Buddha,

dn31:35.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
dn31:35.3.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.

dn31:35.4.pli: Esāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
dn31:35.4.eng: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

dn31:35.5.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhagavā dhāretu, ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
dn31:35.5.eng: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
